title: Knight Frank profits bolstered by Northern revival
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Oct 5, 2015, 01:49 BST - UK Markets open in 6 hrs 11 mins Knight Frank profits bolstered by Northern revival By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 48 minutes ago 0.00 
Demand for commercial property in the North has helped offset weakness in London's prime property market 
A revival in the Northern property market has helped estate agent Knight Frank to another year of record annual profits. 
The property firm posted a 19pc rise in pre-tax profits to £162m while sales climbed by 13pc to £443.1m for the year ending March 31. 
Alistair Elliott, Knight Frank's group chairman and senior partner, said there were a number of investors seeking better value outside of London and Northern-based companies requiring new space as they grew with the improving economy. 
“In the UK, commercial real estate activity has increased and there is now significant life in the sector. Our 10 commercial offices across the UK have had their best year ever.” 
“The regions have spent several years in the doldrums, but we are seeing the commercial lettings market increase, but it must be said this is against a backdrop that has been terrible,” Mr Elliott said. 
However, Knight Frank said that sales of luxury homes had reached a plateau as the market digested the impact of last year’s stamp duty hike. 
Under new stamp duty legislation the homes costing between £925,001 and £1.5m has resulted in an additional 10pc bill, and properties above £1.5m have been hit with an extra 12pc charge. 
Mr Elliott, said that prime property prices were now flat after years of unabated double-digit growth. 
“There’s a period of reflection going on , volumes are weakening and people are more hesitant. It’s a combination of significant price rises over the last few years and the threat of additional taxes. However, there are still some buyers who are interested because of the low interest rate environment and, in some cases, an attractive currency play." 
The group said that its international offices were also performing strongly and demand in its Indian and Australian business was helping to offset China’s slowing economic growth. 
Knight Frank is currently working on the redevelopment of the Shell (LSE: RDSB.L - news ) centre on London’s Southbank which will include 868 homes as well as offices, shops and restaurants. 
Knight Frank, which is one of the biggest partnerhsips in the UK, will split its profits between 65 equity partners, 8,000 staff and reinvestment in the business (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
